xml.name: Search
xml.Text: Searching in AppCode is different. We have special features for searching text and others dedicated to searching code. This is because code is not mere text - it has a specific structure formed by the code constructs.
xml.Try: This sample file has lots of code constructs containing the word test. The caret is on the variable named test. Press Find to find all the text occurrences of the word test.

This is not very helpful, is it? In real code, we probably want to search for the test variable, without including class names, method names, or any other code constructs. Try pressing EditorEscape and then FindUsages.
xml.Text: Now, AppCode shows us only actual usages of the test variable.
xml.Try: The same applies to any other code construct. Press EditorEscape → FindUsages to find all the usages of the Test protocol in the project.
Now let's find all usages of the method test(containsTest test: Int, anotherContainingTest test1: String). Press EditorEscape → FindUsages again.
xml.Text: The simple rule is: think which symbol you need to find, instead of which piece of text you need to find. Find Usages works for any code construct in the project context, so you will find all the usages in the whole codebase.

Of course, sometimes you don't know what exactly you're looking for, and you want to find as many matches as possible by searching for some text. In this case, use Find to search in the current file, or use FindInPath to search in the whole project.
xml.Try: What if you want to search for some text in symbols, file names, or even IDE settings and menu items? Press Double⇧ to open the Search Everywhere dialog.
Finally, try using Find Action (GotoAction) to quickly find an IDE action and execute it. For example, type 'plugins' to open Preferences | Plugins.
